title: 113_s2701
content: The Act titled "Stopping Illegal Obamacare Subsidies Act" limits auto-enrollment in health plans under American Health Benefit Exchanges until inconsistencies are resolved as outlined in the June 2014 report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make public the steps for resolving inconsistencies in eligibility for healthcare programs within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, methods for monitoring progress in resolving inconsistencies will be disclosed within the same timeframe. Suspension of premium assistance tax credits and cost-sharing programs for plan year 2015 until all inconsistencies related to invalid social security numbers are resolved by the Social Security Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services. Requests for additional information may be required from applicants. During an inconsistency period, individuals with inconsistent applicant information may be enrolled in a qualified health plan but cannot access premium assistance credits or reduced cost-sharing programs. The Secretary can request additional information within 90 days for eligibility determination. During an inconsistency period, individuals may be withdrawn from premium assistance credit and reduced cost-sharing programs if they fail to submit requested additional information. The Secretary will notify the health insurance issuer of the disenrollment. During an inconsistency period, individuals may be disenrolled from premium assistance credit and reduced cost-sharing programs for failing to provide additional information. The applicant must re-enroll in a qualified health plan with accurate information during the next open enrollment period. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "inconsistencies" refer to differences in self-attested information provided by an applicant for health plan enrollment and eligibility determination for tax credits, Medicaid, or CHIP, compared to data from the Federal Data Services Hub or other sources, including citizenship, income, employer-sponsored coverage, incarceration status, or other factors affecting eligibility for financial assistance programs. The term "inconsistency period" refers to the 90-day period after a notice of inconsistency is sent to an applicant for financial assistance programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
